title: Authenticated Stored Cross-site Scripting in bbPress
vulnerability_information:
## Description:
There exists a stored XSS vulnerability in bbPress, due to which the XSS payload which I enter in my content, gets executed at **/wp-admin/edit.php?post_type=forum**. This vulnerability requires you to be an authenticated user.

## Steps To Reproduce:
Step 1. Visit /wp-admin/edit.php?post_type=forum
Step 2. Click on **Add New**
Step 3. Write any title, and in content, write your XSS payload through the "Text" editor, rather than the "Visual" one, and publish the content.
Step 4. Now, visit /wp-admin/edit.php?post_type=forum, and you will be able to see the payload getting executed.

## Recommendations
Making use of proper functions in PHP or WordPress core in the bbPress source code regarding the filtering or sanitization of user input is a recommended way to fix this vulnerability.

## Impact

By taking an advantage of this vulnerability, an owner of a WordPress-based website would be able to execute their malicious JavaScript codes in context to the WordPress dashboard, which could result in bad issues to other users.

activities.message:
Hey @binit and @ehtis,

Sorry to say that it appears this report is invalid.

Users with the Administrator Role (having the `unfiltered_html` capability) are able to post nearly any content they'd like. This is a pre-submission trigger for reporting to our program, and it was skipped.

See: https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/testing/reporting-security-vulnerabilities/#why-are-some-users-allowed-to-post-unfiltered-html

When logged in as a user without the `unfiltered_html` capability (say, as a Subscriber) even as a bbPress Keymaster, malicious values are correctly stripped away.

I've attached a gif to show this behavior is working as expected.

If you are able to duplicate this with a user who _does not_ have the `unfiltered_html` capability, please reply with detailed instructions so that we can reopen this report and investigate further.

Thank you for your time and for contributing to bbPress,

activities.message:
Hello @jjj,

Thank you for letting me know about the information regarding this submission!

When the payload in inserted into the forum content area by an administrator, you are able to see the XSS payload gets executed when you visit the **Forums** page in your WordPress dashboard. So, why would any administrator want to perform malicious action on other users of the website by getting their malicious XSS payload executed when they visit the **Forums** page?

I have attached a video explaining this scenario with this response.

Thanks,
@binit

activities.message:
Hey @binit,

Please consider rereading the link I sent previously, which is included in the pre-submission trigger. The very first line explains that:
> Users with Administrator or Editor roles are allowed to publish unfiltered HTML in post titles, post content, and comments, and upload HTML files to the media library

I emphasized the Administrator role in my original reply simply because that is the Site role you used in your testing. The Editor role correctly allows for posting and saving of unfiltered HTML content.

The security team is discussing internally whether the Forums list outputting that same HTML is relevant.

Someone will reply here soon once we’ve come to a decision.

In the meantime, please visit following link and try to understand that what you’ve shown us here not new information, and is the intended behavior. We are discussing whether that behavior needs changing.

https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/testing/reporting-security-vulnerabilities/#why-are-some-users-allowed-to-post-unfiltered-html

Thanks, and talk soon,

activities.message:
After a brief internal discussion, we are going to reopen this report to make sure you are awarded for it. 👍

I've created a public ticket in the bbPress Trac, along with a patch for your review:

https://bbpress.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/3374

We are also discussing a small change to the verbiage in our security policy to better avoid the kind of interaction we've had together here. It's never fun to think you're helping and be told that you're not.

Due to the relatively low severity of this issue, with your approval, it will be committed publicly and released alongside a few other fixes we are working on.

Thank you for working through this with us, and please accept my apology for the added work and misunderstanding.

Talk soon,

activities.message:
Thank you, @binit! 

We've also added some clarifications to our program policy - it's updated to state that self-XSS issues in wp-admin for high privileged users like administrators or editors won't be under the scope of this program. They already are allowed to post JavaScript on the front-end, but within wp-admin, things weren't too clear. So, your issue was considered valid and accepted, plus eligible for bounty.

Going forward though, I hope things will be more clear. Script execution within wp-admin that requires an admin or editor to post it will still need to be fixed, but it won't be a security issue.

All the best and looking forward to hear more in future reports!

summaries.content: **CVE-2020-13487** | The bbPress plugin through 2.6.4 for WordPress has stored XSS in the Forum creation section, resulting in JavaScript execution at *wp-admin/edit.php?post_type=forum* (aka the Forum listing page) for all users. An administrator can exploit this at the *wp-admin/post.php?action=edit* URI.

An administrator can exploit this at the wp-admin/post.php?action=edit URI.
